awd_titl_txt: MRI: Development of a Mobile High-speed Dual Frequency Comb Spectroscopy User Facility
awd_abstract_narration:
Laser light has long been a preferred tool for studying chemical processes in systems ranging from combustion engines, to the atmosphere, to biology. Molecules in these systems absorb light in a specific pattern of colors, and thus can be detected without disturbing the process by shining different colors of light through the sample and quantifying the light pattern that emerges. The frequency comb is a laser source that emits hundreds of thousands of distinct, closely spaced colors of light. When interfered with a second frequency comb in a special process called "dual frequency comb spectroscopy", the light source offers unparalleled potential to probe chemical processes with a combination of color and time resolution that is not available with any other instrument.  This grant will create the first mobile frequency comb user facility – a mobile laboratory that will bring frequency comb technology directly to scientific experiments across the country.  The new capabilities of the frequency comb will enable scientific discovery that benefits human health, the environment, and national security while training a new generation of frequency comb laser engineers.

We will build the first portable and robust high-speed dual-comb spectrometer based on broadband mode-locked frequency combs shifted to the mid-infrared using difference frequency generation.  The dual-comb will be able to simultaneously measure across large portions of the mid-infrared spectral region with tens of thousands of individual wavelength elements and time resolution as low as 10 microseconds.  This will enable in situ, microsecond time resolution movies of chemical dynamic processes unraveling across a multitude of species with unprecedented bandwidth and precision.  The spectrometer will be incorporated into a mobile user facility that will put the dual comb system at the hands of researchers who have never before had access to this technology.  We have assembled a group of 9 initial users and projects at two national labs and four universities that will pilot the user facility to enable scientific breakthroughs across multiple fields spanning chemical kinetics to microscopy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

This project developed a high-speed mid-infrared dual-comb spectrometer mobile user facility, making advanced spectrometry accessible to non-expert users, particularly in chemical kinetics research. The project had two specific goals:

  1. Development of 1-GHz Mid-Infrared Frequency Combs: These combs have broad optical bandwidth and high optical power, essential for high-speed, broadband, and high-resolution dual comb spectroscopy.
  2. Creation of a Mobile Dual-Comb Facility: This facility enables non-experts to conduct high-quality spectrometry experiments.

Key accomplishments included:

  • First Generation System and High Speed Chemical Kinetics: Developed a 1 GHz dual-comb mid-infrared spectrometer used for high-temperature chemical kinetics studies, published in Optica.
  • Hyperspectral Microscopy: Demonstrated high-resolution and high-speed microscopic imaging capabilities, published in APL Photonics.
  • Second Generation System: Mobilized the second generation dual-comb system into a first-of-a-kind mobile dual comb user facility.

Broader Impacts

The project has significant broader impacts across various fields and societal aspects:

  1. Advancement of Knowledge: The project advanced the fields of optical frequency combs and dual-comb spectroscopy by demonstrating a high pulse repetition rate, output power, and optical bandwidth. This combination is crucial for high-speed, broad optical bandwidth dual-comb spectroscopy.
  2. Interdisciplinary Impact: The mobile user facility will impact fields such as combustion, atmospheric chemistry, hypersonics, wildfire research, quantum sensing, and microscopy. These fields will benefit from high-speed, broadband, and high-resolution absorption spectroscopy capabilities.
  3. Human Resource Development: The project provided training opportunities for two PhD students, who gained valuable skills in nonlinear optics, spectroscopy, and software development. The collaboration between engineering and physics groups enriched the impact for both parties.
  4. Infrastructure Development: The project created the first mobile dual-comb spectroscopy user facility, which is expected to become a model for new, more flexible user facilities.
  5. Technology Transfer: The team participated in customer discovery workshops and won support for commercial steps, exploring potential replacements for traditional GC-MS devices. The dual-comb spectrometer could enable high-speed measurements not possible with GC-MS, facilitating source localization of atmospheric pollutant emitters.
  6. Societal Impact: The dual-comb spectrometer will enable discoveries in various fields, leading to cleaner, more efficient engines, better healthcare and defense, and cleaner air through improved pollutant detection.

Dissemination of Results

The project results have been widely disseminated through:

  • Journal Articles: Four published articles, with one more under review.
  • Conference Presentations: Twelve presentations, including five invited talks and a plenary session.
  • Invited Seminars: Presentations at various universities and research institutions.
